The @polkadotnetwork client contains #rustlang code that governs the blockchain. But the same code also exists in #wasm in the chain itself.

If this WASM code changes (after a vote), all the clients automatically switch from the native code to an interpreter.

Cool, isn't it?

1049216214822801409.text: • The ability to immediately start running your project on @polkadotnetwork. Although projects built with Substrate can be compiled to use seperate clients per-project, since Polkadot implements the Substrate API you can tap into Polkadot's shared security and interopability.

1049216213199540224.text: • Seamless client updates - any update that could affect consensus is  handled by compiling the code to WebAssembly and deploying it as just  another message on the network.

1049216211853238272.text: • A cross-platform database/file storage abstraction, which even works in-browser.

1049216210473287682.text: • The ability to seamlessly run a node in the browser that can communicate with any desktop or cloud node.

1049216208279687171.text: • An efficient, deterministic, sandboxed WebAssembly runtime. This can be used to run smart contracts or even to run other Substrate-based projects.

1049216205083611138.text: • Consensus, finality and block voting logic. Even if you're not building a  cryptocurrency or even a project that requires a blockchain, this is desirable—it means that for free you can get byzantine fault tolerance.

1049216200109150208.text: If you want to build a new project using Substrate, all you have to do is implement a very small number of hooks in your code. Then for free you get...:pic.twitter.com/ufOTNGM90k

How GRANDPA finality gadget works:

Here nodes 1-3 have voted for the highest valid block. Block C is the highest block with a supermajority of votes. Because these participants make up more than 2/3 of the stake, the block is finalised.
